Key Arguments: The legislation threatens freedom of expression, a fundamental human right.
The power given to ACMA could lead to censorship and suppression of dissenting opinions.
Misinformation is subjective and what is considered misinformation can change over time.
Censorship is a step towards authoritarianism and undermines democratic ideals.
The bill could put Australia in breach of its international human rights obligations.
Notable Quotes: In a democracy, freedom of expression is vital.
All silencing of discussion is an assumption of infallibility.
Illiberal measures to control online mischief would be far more harmful than the misinformation itself.
The impulse to decide which speech constitutes 'misinformation' and must be censored is, at heart, totalitarian.
